12592.title: Indian Girl with Parrot and Hoop
12592.creation_notes: Keep earliest/latest dates as 1922/1923. This painting is included on a list of paintings made in 1922 and 1923, written by the artist. Copy of the original list is in historical file. Ellen Lee, Senior Curator, prefers "about 1922" as the primary date.
12592.credit_line: Gift in memory of John P. Frenzel, Sr., by his heirs
12592.provenance: (Pettis Gallery, Indianapolis); John P. Frenzel, Sr., Indianapolis, in 1924; by descent to his children; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1973.

extended_text.content:
This canvas, with its intricate linear construction, exhibits the artist's dramatic use of brilliant color.

Pueblo people used parrots as a source of feathers to decorate ceremonial objects.

Indiana-born Higgins gained his fame as a Western artist painting in Taos, New Mexico.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

2101.title: potsherd
2101.creation_notes: "Earliest" date = 3000 BC because that is the earliest artifact from the Native Arts of the Americas collection known to have been made in the (now) US;"Latest" date = accession year. These fields are filled out somewhat arbitrarily for search purposes only; the Earliest/Latest dates were not provided by Mellon Curator Dr. Christian Feest and should not be used or provided outside the IMA.

68272.title: Ship and Shells
68272.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in memory of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Mrs. H. E. Conant
68272.medium_support: woodblock print on cream Japan paper
68272.provenance: (Steven Thomas, Inc., Woodstock, New York); purchased by Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2009.
68272.inscription:
Inscribed in pencil, below image, l.l.:  "Ships and Shells"
Signed and dated in pencil, below image, l.r.:  Mildred McMillen 1923

extended_text.content:
McMillen had gone to Paris with Ada Gilmore in 1913, worked with Maud Squire and Ethel Mars and all returned together in 1914. Reunited in Provincetown, the group spent the winter of 1915 devoting themselves to woodblock printmaking. While the others worked in color, McMillen worked almost exclusively in black and white.

After World War I ended in 1918, many of the core group of Provincetown Printers returned to Europe, but McMillen and her longtime friend Gilmore settled in Provincetown.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

68272.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

72369.title: Untitled (Lily)
72369.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in memory of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Mrs. H. E. Conant
72369.medium_support: watercolor over pencil on cream wove paper
72369.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2011.
72369.inscription: Signed in black ink, l.c.: Ada Gilmore

extended_text.content:
Ada Gilmore met Mildred McMillen while a student at the Art Institute of Chicago in 1903. The two went to Paris in 1913 where they became friends and part-time students of the American printmakers Ethel Mars and Maud Squire.

Gilmore, McMillen, Mars and Squire left France together at the outbreak of World War I in 1914 and the next summer they travelled to Provincetown. While Mars and Squire returned to France after the war, Gilmore and McMillen settled in Provincetown.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

72369.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

76180.title: Fish Shacks
76180.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in memory of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Mrs. H. E. Conant
76180.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2012.

extended_text.content:
Weinrich made her first prints in Provincetown under the tutelage of Blanche Lazzell, who would become her life-long friend. She began exhibiting with the Provincetown Printers in 1917.

Fish Shacks, a simple print made from a square of carved linoleum, was intended for a promotional book, A Modern Pilgrim’s Print Book, published by the Provincetown Art Association in 1935.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

76180.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

33321.title: Portrait of William Francklyn Paris
33321.title_notes:
Ronald G. Pisano, William Merritt Chase: Portraits in Oil, cat. rais. vol. 2 (New Haven and London: Yale University Press, 2006), pp. 202-203.
Stet use of "c" in "Francklyn," per primary source research. See Rebecca McNamara's notes in the historical file.
33321.creation_notes: Ronald G. Pisano, William Merritt Chase: Portraits in Oil, cat. rais. vol. 2 (New Haven and London: Yale University Press, 2006), pp. 202-203.
33321.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mr. and Mrs. H. L. Conant
33321.inscription: Inscribed and signed, l.l.:  To my friend / W. F. Paris / Wm. M. Chase

extended_text.content:
William Merritt Chase

Portrait of William Francklyn Paris, about 1891

oil on canvas

20 x 16 inches

Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mr. and Mrs. H. L. Conant

Learn More

William Merritt Chase was born in Ninevah, Indiana and studied under Barton Hayes in Indianapolis and then briefly at the National Academy of Design.  Due to the interest and generosity of several art patrons, Chase was able to take a five-year trip to Munich, where he studied at the city’s Royal Academy.  In 1878, Chase returned to New York City, opened his Tenth Street Studio and developed his signature impressionist style.  He was a member of America’s influential group of impressionists known as The Ten, but was also an extremely influential teacher.  Chase opened the first summer school of landscape painting at his summer home in Shinnecock, Long Island.  He also taught at the Chase School in New York, which he founded, and the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.  His students included such famous artists as Marsden Hartley, Charles Demuth, Edward Hopper, Georgia O’Keeffe and Charles Sheeler.

This lively image reveals the stylistic progression Chase had undergone since he painted William Gurley Munson (58.31). Paris’ facial features are broadly brushed in a freer, more spirited manner than the tight handling of the Munson portrait.  However, consistent in both images is Chase’s technique of animating the composition by bathing the forehead of the sitter with stark, bright light.  The subject of the portrait, a noted architect, was also a student and friend of Chase. When Chase was in need of money, Paris helped the artist by commissioning portraits of several of his clients. Through his efforts, a bust of Chase was placed in the Pantheon of Painters and Sculptors in the Hall of Remembrance of New York University in 1930.

Reference

Ronald G. Pisano.  William Merritt Chase: The Complete Catalogue of Known and Documents Work by William Merritt Chase (1849-1916), Vol. 2: Portraits in Oil, New Haven Connecticut: Yale University Press, 2007.  ISBN-13: 978-0300110210
extended_text.title: Indiana

18309.title: The Dory
18309.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mr. and Mrs. H. L. Conant
18309.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1989.
18309.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: The Dory | stamped in black, below image, L.R.: 00161 | signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: Mabel A. Hewit
rights: © Mabel A. Hewit, Courtesy of the artist's estate and Mary Ryan Gallery

extended_text.content: Hewit, an Ohio art teacher, began making black and white woodblock prints during the summer of 1930 in Provincetown. In 1933 she took a class with Blanche Lazzell in the method of the Provincetown specialty, the single-block, white-line color woodcut. The Dory resembles Lazzell’s own black-and-white woodcuts of the late 1920s and early 1930s.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

18309.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

26185.title: Rue Arabe - Algiers
26185.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
26185.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
26185.inscription: signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: Ora Inge Maxim | inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: Rue Arabe - Algiers

extended_text.content: Rue Arabe—Algiers was the result of a trip Maxim took with fifteen other artists to Europe and North Africa in 1930. The print would have been made after her instruction in white-line printmaking in 1931.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

26185.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

9124.title: Stark Country
9124.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
9124.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.

extended_text.content: Gearhart joined the fledgling Print Makers Society of California in 1919. From then until failing eyesight forced her to abandon printmaking in 1940, she invariably showed several prints at the Society’s annual exhibition, usually dramatic vistas of the California coast or the Sierra Nevada Mountains around Big Bear Lake where she had a vacation home.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

9124.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

12660.title: Big Sister
12660.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
12660.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
12660.inscription: signed in pencil, below image, L.L.: Eliza D. Gardiner | signed and numbered in pencil, in image, L.L.: Eliza D. Gardiner 40/50 | inscribed in pencil, below image, L.C.: BIG SISTER | inscribed in pencil, below image, L.R.: 40/50

extended_text.content:
Gardiner was steeped in the Arts and Crafts tradition, one of the manifestations of which was her color woodblock printmaking, which she taught at the Rhode Island School of Design in Providence beginning in 1908. She was one of many women woodblock printmakers in this era (as suggested by this exhibition) and practitioners of the various Arts and Crafts.

She first associated with the Provincetown Printers at their founding in 1916, though she remained true to the traditional multi-block method of color printing and never seems to have adopted the white-line technique.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

12660.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

12659.title: Horse and Cart
12659.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
12659.inscription: signed in pencil, on mount, L.R.: E. Mars

extended_text.content:
Mars and Squire were well known in American art circles in Paris. Gertrude Stein wrote one of her early word portraits about the pair. They lived a few doors down from fellow woodcut specialist, Edna Boies Hopkins, who had been a friend since student days in Cincinnati. Mars taught woodblock printmaking to Mildred McMillen and Ada Gilmore in 1913 and all five of these artists were reunited in Provincetown in 1915.

Brittany was the preferred summer retreat for Mars and Squire while in France and Horse and Cart was likely made there.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

12659.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

20705.title: Child with a Hoop
20705.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
20705.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
20705.inscription: initialed in pencil, L.R.: E D G | inscribed in pencil, L.L.: 7/25

extended_text.content:
Children on the beaches at Provincetown and Edgewater, Rhode Island provided Gardiner with the majority of her subjects in the 1910s and 1920s when she was at her most active as a printmaker.

The simplicity of her designs and bold forms of her figures rescue Gardiner’s work from the excessive sentimentality that is common to such subject matter.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

20705.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

20707.title: Provincetown Houses
20707.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
20707.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
20707.inscription: signed in pencil below image L.L.: MA FRACK

extended_text.content: The only record of the artist Mary Alice Frack lists her as an exhibitor with the Print Club in the 1930s in Philadelphia where she resided. No visits to Provincetown are known, but the subject and the method used in this white-line woodcut are evidence that she was there, perhaps studying with Blanche Lazzell, the town’s most constant instructor in printmaking.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

20707.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

11953.title: Provincetown Wharf
11953.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
11953.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
11953.inscription: inscribed in ink, below image, L.L.: Provincetown Wharf | signed in ink, below image, L.R.: B. Lazzell

extended_text.content:
While Lazzell was a colorist, she occasionally experimented in small, black and white woodcuts and linocuts such as Provincetown Wharf.

Such works “express volume and strength by the use of geometric forms,” which Lazzell wrote was the aim of Cubism.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

11953.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

4322.title: My Studio
4322.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
4322.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
4322.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: My Studio | signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: B. Lazzell

extended_text.content: In 1926 Lazzell built a large, new studio in Provincetown. The vine-clad building and the wharf upon which it sat are featured in this linocut.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

4322.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

12260.title: Taos Village with Pueblo Indians
12260.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
12260.provenance: Dr. Stephen Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
12260.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: Taos Street Scene | signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: Barbara Latham

extended_text.content:
Taos Plaza was the center of village life where Anglos, Hispanics and Native Americans freely mixed. Taos’ isolated location, far from the railroad, preserved its Wild West flavor well into the 20th century.

Latham, an illustrator of greeting cards, came to New Mexico in 1925, probably on the recommendation of her former teacher Andrew Dasburg. She met and married the printmaker Howard Cook in 1927 and they settled in Taos.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

12260.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

24477.title: The First Noel
24477.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
24477.provenance: Dr. Stephen Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
24477.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: "The First Noël" | inscribed in pencil, below image, L.C.: imp | signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: Mary Mullineux
24477.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

13486.title: From the Roof
13486.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
13486.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
13486.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: From the Roof | signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: Mabel A. Hewit
rights: © Mabel A. Hewit, Courtesy of the artist's estate and Mary Ryan Gallery

extended_text.content:
Hewit continued to produce black-and-white and color woodcuts for thirty years after settling in 1934 in Cleveland, the likely setting for From the Roof.

“I like block printing because it gives the family of modest means an opportunity to have something of color and art in their homes.” — Mable Hewit
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

13486.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

21450.title: The Wild Goose
21450.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
21450.provenance: Dr. Steve Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
21450.inscription: signed in ink L.R.: Ada Gilmore; signed, dated and inscribed in ink below image L.R.: A. Gilmore. 1923. / Provincetown

extended_text.content:
In 1952 Ada Gilmore recorded the invention of the innovative single block “white-line” woodcut by B.J.O. Nordfeldt, Ethel Mars, Maud Squire, Mildred McMillen, Juliette Nichols and herself during the winter of 1916 that they spent together making prints in Provincetown.

Gilmore’s single-block woodcuts, such as The Wild Goose, are softer and more imaginative than the severely geometric and matter-of-fact woodcuts typical of her fellow Provincetown printers.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

21450.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

35367.title: Navajo Land
35367.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
35367.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
35367.inscription: signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: Norma Bassett Hall | inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: Ed. 100 NAVAJO LAND

extended_text.content:
Hall was a native Oregonian and developed an interest in color blockprinting while on her honeymoon in 1922 with her husband, the painter-printmaker Arthur Hall. They settled in Kansas, spent two years in Europe, and returned to help found the Prairie Print Makers in Kansas in 1930.

In 1942 the Halls settled in Santa Fe and it was probably at that time that Norma produced Navajo Land, depicting the area of western New Mexico and eastern Arizona.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

35367.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

8122.title: Purple Daisy (also known as Chrysanthème Simple)
8122.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
8122.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1991.
8122.inscription: signed in pencil, below image L.L.: Edna Boies Hopkins

extended_text.content:
Hopkins mastered the Japanese technique of color woodblock printmaking in Japan in 1904, which was evident in the sensitive floral woodcuts she produced in Paris where she and her husband settled in 1906.

At the onset of war in 1914, Hopkins returned to the United States and summered the next year in Provincetown where she associated with other woodblock artists she had known in Paris. In Provincetown she experimented with landscapes and figure subjects in the novel single-block technique. She returned to Paris in 1921.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

8122.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012 | "Dining with Flowers:  Haviland Porcelain from 1860-1910," University of Iowa Museum of Art, Iowa City, Iowa, 06/22/2000-08/13/2000|

25527.title: The Dreamy Lobster
25527.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenberger
25527.medium_support: color relief etching and engraving with stenciled color
25527.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1999.
25527.inscription:
inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: 2-60
signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: G. Peterdi
rights: © The Estate of Gabor F. Peterdi

extended_text.content:
In 1940, Stanley William Hayter and many other artists of Atelier 17 fled the Nazi occupation of Paris and reestablished their studio in New York. Peterdi, having served in the US Army during the war, reconnected with Atelier 17 in 1947.

Peterdi’s first color prints were made in 1947 with the simple application of watercolor brushed onto the engravings through stencils. The Dreamy Lobster was published in a portfolio of prints issued by a new New York gallery, Laurels, which became a prime outlet for the artists of Atelier 17.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

25527.exhibit_history: "Gabor Peterdi", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 01/11/2013-01/05/2014

38935.title: Untitled (Provincetown Dock with Figure)
38935.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in memory of Mrs. H. L. Conant
38935.medium_support: watercolor over pencil on white paper
38935.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2000.
38935.inscription: signed and dated in pencil, L.R.: A. WALKOWITZ / 1917 | signed in ink, L.L.: A. Walkowitz

extended_text.content:
Walkowitz was among the traditionally trained American painters who turned toward abstraction after their introduction to such artists as Cézanne, Picasso and Kandinsky in Europe in the early years of the 20th century.

The watercolors that he did on vacation in Provincetown were more relaxed than his abstract oils of Manhattan, but even they strike a “modern note” as was said of the white-line woodcuts being produced in Provincetown at the same time.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

38935.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

76179.title: Gathering Quahogs
76179.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in memory of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Mrs. H. E. Conant
76179.provenance: Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2012.

extended_text.content:
Knaths’ linocut of a clam digger appeared with Agnes Weinrich’s linocut in The Modern Pilgrim’s Print Book published in Provincetown in 1935.

Like Weinrich, Knaths was an early American modernist who received inspiration from the revolutionary European works displayed at the Armory Show. He settled permanently in Provincetown in 1919 and married Weinrich’s sister.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

76179.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012

34175.title: boy's three piece suit
34175.title_notes: A) jacket B) shorts C) blouse D) hat
34175.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Robert S. Harcourt
34175.provenance: Mrs. Robert S. Harcourt, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1970.
